creditline: Gift of Jerry Rothstein in memory of Miriam Meyers Rothstein, 1946-2024: Olympian, Poet, Woman of Valor
culture: Penelakut Coast Salish and Cape Mudge Kwakwaka'wakw
description: circular image of a whale with face below and tail wrapping overhead, dorsal fin in center; black body is covered with brightly colored shapes in yellow, red, blues, orange, white; pair of eyes on tail; on a light blue background; printed on white paper
inscription:
lower left, graphite: A/P 3/10
BC, graphite: \'PROTECTOR\'
life_date: Canadian (Penelakut Coast Salish and Cape Mudge Kwakwaka'wakw), born 1973
nationality: Canadian (Penelakut Coast Salish and Cape Mudge Kwakwaka'wakw)
signed: lower right, graphite: Maynard Johnny Jr
text: Rich in cultural symbolism, Maynard Johnny's boldly designed color screenprint conveys the story of an orca, or killer whale, who encounters a young child whose canoe has overturned in a storm. The whale, taking on the role of protector, brings the child safely ashore. For Indigenous people, the orca symbolizes family, romance, longevity, harmony, travel, community and protection. Orcas are said to protect those who travel away from home, and to lead them back in due course. For Johnny, this story emphasizes the importance of protecting Indigenous youth, culture, and community so future generations will prosper.
title: Protector
